docs.lead_paragraph: The city held out unlimited promise. The reality was a struggle, for money, identity and a future.

headline.main: 'New York Was Our City on the Hill'
headline.sub: The city held out unlimited promise. The reality was a struggle, for money, identity and a future. ;

docs.snippet: The city held out unlimited promise. The reality was a struggle, for money, identity and a future.

docs.lead_paragraph: ELISE JACOBS had to travel around the world before figuring out there's no place like home. Ten years ago, Ms. Jacobs left Sag Harbor, where she and seven generations of her family had grown up, to attend the University of Colorado. A lifelong sailor, she missed the ocean but loved the majestic Rockies. After college, she crewed on a sailing yacht that took her to the Caribbean for nine months. Then she spent nearly five years backpacking across Southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.
docs.snippet: ELISE JACOBS had to travel around the world before figuring out there's no place like home.    Ten years ago, Ms. Jacobs left Sag Harbor, where she and seven generations of her family had grown up, to attend the University of Colorado. A lifelong...

docs.lead_paragraph: NOTHING happened in my life for three years. Then, in 10 days, everything happened. One night, I was at a nightclub in La Rioja, the kind of place with a lot of drugs and a lot of people who you weren't quite sure how they made a living, when someone called me a drug addict in front of my girlfriend. So I punched him. It turned out he was a powerful drug dealer whose uncle was a judge. The police came after me, and suddenly, La Rioja became very small.
docs.abstract: Essay by Javier F, told to and translated by Seth Kugel, on moving in 2001 at age 32 to Sunnyside, Queens, from Argentina; describes trying to adjust to cultural and economic differences and working and living without documents in city; photo; map (Special Issue: The Next Wave) (M)
docs.snippet: I needed a dictionary to translate the culture of New York City when I came from Argentina. I was reborn with a blank slate, and now, I am barely starting to speak.

byline.original: By JAVIER F.; As told to Seth Kugel, who translated from the Spanish

docs.lead_paragraph: A seductive new diagnostic technology may be coming to a medical center near you. It is an advanced heart scanner that can produce sharply detailed pictures of every clogged artery that might be threatening to cause a heart attack. Some experts expect it to revolutionize the practice of cardiology, while others are warning that it could bankrupt the health care system. Even discounting for hyperbole on both sides, it will be important to ensure that this technology is used only on the most appropriate patients and not promoted willy-nilly for every anxious man or woman eager to exploit the latest medical fad. As described by Gina Kolata in Wednesday's Times, the technology is a vastly more powerful version of the CT scanners that have long been used to construct X-ray images of various organs in the body. Cardiologists have been frustrated that those scanners produce only blurry images of the fast-beating heart and its arteries, but now, by adding a lot more detectors, the new machines are able to produce pictures of startling detail and clarity. In the long run, the new scanners could replace the stress test, which some patients find too arduous to perform, and the much more expensive angiogram, an invasive procedure that requires threading a catheter from the groin to the heart with the patient under sedation. Heart scans are expected to cost about $700, compared with roughly $4,000 for an angiogram.

headline.main: The Promise and Peril of Heart Scans

docs.abstract: Editorial holds that some experts expect new advanced heart scanner to revolutionize practice of cardiology, while others warn that it could bankrupt health care system; contends that technology should be used only on most appropriate patients and not promoted for every anxious man or woman eager to exploit latest medical fad; maintains that professional groups should issue guidelines on who will benefit from scanners, and insurers should limit reimbursements to those who meet guidelines0
docs.snippet: Used sensibly, heart scans could save the health care system substantial money. Used recklessly, however, the scans could break the medical bank.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed at soaring pharmaceutical costs, states are trying a wide range of new tactics to curb spending on prescription drugs for Medicaid recipients, public employees, prisoners and other residents, bringing them into lobbying combat with the drug industry. A dozen states have joined purchasing pools in an attempt to use market power to reduce costs. Dozens more are requiring Medicaid recipients to use generic or lower-priced drugs from preferred lists.

headline.main: States Trying New Tactics to Reduce Spending on Drugs

docs.abstract: Rising pharmaceutical costs are prompting states to form purchasing pools in effort to obtain lower prices; Medicaid spending increased almost 50 percent in last four years and will exceed state spending on elementary and secondary education for first time in 2004; laws in some states call for use of generic drugs where available and have established lists of preferred drugs; pharmaceutical industry has been unsuccessful in challenges; West Virginia is among states seeking to negotiate discounts on drug purchases for state programs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Drug companies are fighting most of the state initiatives, which they say will deny patients access to valuable treatments.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and JAMES DAO

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a city where real estate is both spectacle and obsession, the Time Warner Center has played a prominent role in New York's millennial epic. Emerging from years of struggle over the future of Columbus Circle, the project passed through the crucible of Sept. 11, 2001 (steel was going up and condominium sales were in their fourth week when the World Trade Center was leveled) and into a real estate boom of big-name architects (David Childs of Skidmore Owings & Merrill designed it), celebrity buyers (the pop star Ricky Martin took an apartment) and stratospheric prices. If nothing else, the two-pronged complex, like a giant tuning fork vibrating to the zeitgeist, has given the current boom its biggest number and the city its most expensive apartment ever: the 76th-story, full-floor condo that the Mexican-born financier David Martinez bought in the summer of 2003 for $42.25 million.

headline.main: Who's Who, and What They Paid

docs.abstract: Time Warner Center's two towers have given current Manhattan residential real estate boom its most expensive apartment ever: 76th-story full-floor condo David Martinez bought in 2003 for $42.25 million; Louise M Sunshine, whose company markets apartments at center, developed by Related Cos and Apollo Real Estate Advisors, says they are about 85 percent sold; puts total sales so far at $810 million; buyers and sources of their wealth noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In a city where real estate is both spectacle and obsession, the Time Warner Center has played a prominent role in New York's millennial epic.

docs.lead_paragraph: Interrogated this year by U.S. investigators in his Iraq prison cell about prewar U.N. inspections, Tariq Aziz quoted Saddam Hussein as having told his manipulative Higher Committee in 2002, '' 'These people are playing a game with us -- we'll play a game with them.' '' That technique is known in the American vernacular as gaming the system. This summer, President Bush said of Saddam Hussein, ''Intelligence clearly says that he was gaming the system.'' In an October news conference, the president used the phrase redundantly: ''The Duelfer report showed that Saddam was systematically gaming the system, using the U.N. oil-for-food program to try to influence countries . . . to undermine sanctions.''

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 11-21-04: ON LANGUAGE

docs.abstract: William Safire On Language column explores roots of 'to game,' in light of current usage, 'gaming the system,' and of 'kumbaya,' which derives from creole and has come to mean 'excessively idealistic' (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Looking back, Mark and Cheryl Miller would have done a lot of things differently with their 13-year-old son, Matt. They probably would never have left Lenexa, Kan. They would have sent him to a different school, and they certainly would have chosen a different therapist. But most of all, they wouldn't have given him Zoloft. ''It's not a pleasant thing living with the thought that you had a hand in your son's death,'' Mark Miller told me recently. ''Making him take those pills was done out of love for Matt, but it was still the wrong thing to do.'' We were on our way back from Mark and Cheryl's Wednesday-night Bible-study class. I was riding with Mark, who had come straight from the advertising agency where he works as a vice president and creative director. A young-looking 55, with neatly combed hair and wire-rimmed glasses, he was wearing a striped Polo button-down and pressed blue jeans. A few minutes later Mark eased his white Volvo into the garage of their home, a meticulously decorated two-story Tudor in Overland Park, Kan. The Millers moved here from Lenexa, like Overland Park a suburb of Kansas City, in the summer of 1996, though they'd been talking about relocating for years. They liked Lenexa, but Mark was doing well, and they could afford a bigger house in a more upscale neighborhood.
docs.abstract: Jonathan Mahler article explores use of antidepressants by teenagers, in light of FDA finding that they may trigger suicidal thoughts in that age group; cites case of Matt Miller, 13, who killed himself after just several days on Zoloft, and lawsuit filed by his parents against Pfizer; question is complicated by fact that patients who are prescribed antidepressants are, by definition, vulnerable to suicidal behavior, making it difficult to determine where effects of depression end and where effects of drug begin; many child psychiatrists believe FDA overreached in its decision, leaving them with few tools to combat teenage mental health problems; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Since the F.D.A. has issued a strong warning about adolescent use of antidepressants, will the inevitable decrease in prescriptions ultimately lead to more teenage suicides?

docs.lead_paragraph: Local elected officials across New York have been trying to explain to their constituents all year that in order to cover the soaring costs of Medicaid, services must often be pared down to avoid raising already-high property taxes. To that end, the Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, floated an old idea of his. He wanted to put a line on each county property tax bill listing how many dollars each resident pays to cover the county's costs for Medicaid, the federal and state health insurance program for the poor.

headline.main: Proposal to Tell Taxpayers Of Medicaid Cost Falters

docs.abstract: Westchester County Exec Andrew J Spano's proposal to put line on each county property tax bill listing how many dollars each resident pays to cover county's costs for Medicaid falters after 1199/SEIU president Dennis Rivera writes letter to Spano and members of County Board of Legislators opposing idea (M)
docs.snippet: ALBANY, Nov. 19 - Local elected officials across New York have been trying to explain to their constituents all year that in order to cover the soaring costs of Medicaid, services must often be pared down to avoid raising already-high property taxes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after hundreds of bodies were found scattered, stacked and left to rot at the Tri-State Crematory, its manager pleaded guilty on Friday to theft, fraud, making false statements and abuse of a dead body. At a hearing in Walker County Superior Court, the manager, Ray Brent Marsh, who left his senior year in college in 1996 to take over operations at his parents' cremating business in Noble when his father's health failed, turned to families of some of the dead and apologized.

headline.main: Guilty Plea and Apology From Crematory Manager

docs.abstract: Tri-State Crematory manager Ray Brent Marsh pleads guilty to theft, fraud, making false statements and abuse of dead body nearly three years after hundreds of bodies were left to rot at Noble, Ga, crematory; Marsh, under plea bargain, will receive 12 years in prison, with eligibility for parole; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Nearly three years after hundreds of bodies were found scattered, stacked and left to rot at the Tri-State Crematory, its manager pleaded guilty on several counts.
